html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div h1 span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: To go on the academic job market requires that by late November you have onepretty good paper, and two paper ideas. When first sending your packet todepartments, ask for a faculty list with research interests, so you will knowwith whom you are dealing.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div h3 span
content: Questions you are likely to be asked many times

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span span span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Prepare a five minute talk. Sound enthusiastic!Realize that most of your interviewers know little about your field, so providelots of motivation for your study. Practice the talk with friends before themeetings.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span span span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Prepare answers to the three or four mostfrequent questions and criticisms of your work.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span span span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Prepare a few thoughts about further researchconcerning your thesis.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: 2. When do you think you will finish your dissertation?

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Your odds of landing a job are higher if you can convincingly argue you willbe done by June (best) or at least by September. Employers do not like newassistant professors to arrive with unfinished dissertations (although manysuch assistant professors exist).

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: 3. What are you thinking about working on next?

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Describe one or two research projects that you would like to work on next.You don't need to carry out these exact projects. You can include extensions ofyour thesis: ideas it has spawned, or tests of it you will someday do. At leastone idea should be distinct from your thesis. On the other hand, don't bescattered. Most of your ideas should hang together, as if you were writing abook or two.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: 4. What courses would you like to teach?

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Be sure to know the needs of the department before answering this one.Mention undergrad and grad courses, and perhaps an advanced grad course. Theadvanced courses are sought after; don't sound as if you demand to teach one.Mention a service course (intro, micro, or macro) that you are willing toteach.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Know the text you might use in the course, particularly for undergraduates.(You can ask around for plausible texts, and perhaps reading lists.) Thinkabout an outline of topics for one or two courses.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div h3 span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: The interviews are also for you to find out things. Also, asking questionsshows you are interested, and fills gaps in the conversation that theincompetent interviewers leave when they run out of things to say. Do notdiscuss money. There is lots of time for that.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span span span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Facilities: library, research assistants,computers, research institutes, etc.

content: The importance of asking good questions

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p a span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span span span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span

html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div h3 span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: The key to the interview is to be enthusiastic. Interviewers are looking for(1) people who would accept an offer, and (2) nice colleagues. The firstconsideration implies that you should have a reason why the interviewer'sschool is really your first choice ("Oh, I just love -40 in winter andsearing heat in summer," she explained to the Minnesotans). The secondpoint implies that you must be friendly, witty, and easygoing (during thehigh-pressure meetings!).

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: is more important than being friendlyand collegial. They are looking for someone they would like to have lunch withevery day-this dominates most other criteria.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: This is just one in a series of David Levine's Cheap Advice. Collect themall! Dazzle your friends! Feel free to circulate to anyone who might find themuseful.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p a span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p a span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p a span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p a span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Write to David Levine, Haas School of Business, University of California,Berkeley CA 94720; levine@haas.berkeley.edu for additional Cheap Advice, or togive Cheap Advice back to the source. Feedback is always appreciated.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div h1 span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div h1 a span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div h1 span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: I was trained as a graduate student to read other people's research. Then Ifinished my special field exams and was told to go write some research. Icompare my experience to learning how to read literature, then being asked to docreative writing. Not unrelated, but hardly the same set of skills. Here issome advice I found helpful when I was searching for a topic.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: : Choosing a paper topic requiresbalancing the importance and feasibility of the topic. Feasibility involvestractability for theoretical research, and data availability for empiricalresearch. I recommend creating a number of one-page paper proposals, each witha topic sentence and data source.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: There are several heuristics for finding researchable paper topics. One wayis to list three of four papers you like. This list may hint at the style,political point of view, level of abstraction, and methods that are appropriatefor you.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Other paper ideas are motivated by bad research, not good: find statementsby policy-makers, analysts and journalists that make you angry, and find datasets to address the issue. When studying for exams, keep a list of stupidthings you read to return to during the dissertation stage.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Don't be afraid of normal science: repeating in a longitudinal data set whatothers have done only in the cross section. Some paper ideas are data-driven:read codebooks from a variety of data sets and see if certain questions sparkideas or tests of theories you find interesting. For every paper you read,think what else you would have done with that dataset or methodology.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: , not a dissertation. A dissertation can be a dauntingprospect. If possible, focus on a 25-page paper with a clear one-sentencetopic. If you like this paper, then it can become the basis of a dissertation.I promise you that just about any topic can grow to 150 pages; nearly alltopics students first choose are WAY too broad.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
content: A dissertation is any stack of papers with three signatures on the top sheet

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p i span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: . It lived up to that title, and remains aclassic to this day. I initially felt that my dissertation should be, if notthat good, at least vaguely comparable in the sense of answering one of the BigQuestions.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Do not fall prey, as I did, to the "magnum opus fallacy". Adissertation should be normal science that certifies your competency. Save thebig thoughts in a file, and get finished! Write an opus when you are a professor,and are being paid for it. Meanwhile, negotiate the smallest useful chunk ofthe Big Project with your dissertation advisers, and do that single piece ofresearch.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: . Having folks to bounce your ideasoff of at an early stage is irreplaceable. The members of your dissertationgroup do not need to have similar fields; any smart person will be useful ateach stage of a project, from vague ideas through research design, and writeup. All you need are people who are willing to listen to raw ideas, and willingto read first "pre-drafts" of chapters.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: This is just one in a series of David Levine's Cheap Advice. Collect themall! Dazzle your friends! Feel free to circulate to anyone who might find themuseful.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p a span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p a span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p a span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p a span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Write to David Levine, Haas School of Business, University of California,Berkeley CA 94720; levine@haas.berkeley.edu for additional Cheap Advice, or togive Cheap Advice back to the source. Feedback is always appreciated.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div h1 a span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div h1 span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: When people evaluate you for tenure, they need to know (1) who you are, and(2) what (one or two sentences) results you are associated with. Thus, my basicadvice is focus your research, get it read, and get seen. Sadly, the visibilityof yourself is as important as the quality of your work in professionalsuccess.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: : You should think of your research as writing a book,not articles. The idea is that your first five years' research should involveone or two unifying themes.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: The reason for sticking to a theme is that people evaluating you need to beable to say "This young scholar is one of the world's experts at_______." You get to fill the blank. However, your work must hold togetherso that there is

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: word or phrase they can stick in the blank.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: In an ideal world, academics would be able to study any important topic theywere competent to shed light on. In the real world, assistant professors arebeing evaluated; you don't need to play the game I describe, but now you knowthe rules.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: : List people who should read your papers. The list shouldinclude at least three groups: a dozen or so senior people in your field whoare likely to write letters evaluating you when you go up for tenure;classmates and other buddies who are likely to actually read the stuff; andpeople who work on related topics and you would like to cite your stuff. Makeup a master list that receives most papers, and modify it for each paper. Lookat each paper's bibliography for ideas on who might want to see it. (Everyonewants to see papers that cite them -- that's why so many professors read papersfrom the back.)

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Typically you should mail out papers in their working paper stage, one draftbefore submission.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Feedback is crucial. All research has flaws, and all drafts haveeasy-to-correct flaws. Make sure your research and writing has lots of feedbackto fix both types. Especially for the clarity issues, be open minded. If yourparents, friends, colleagues in unrelated disciplines, will read the sucker,send it to them!

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: : Travel every year to give seminars. If you are going to benear a university, call up six months early and tell them you are available andwould like to give a seminar.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Don't be shy: figure out how to give a talk at your field's annualconvention, and do it! Invite a mix of friends and more well-known people.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
content: Learn how to be a Manager

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: : Secretaries and research assistants arejust a few of the people you need to learn to manage. The secrets are few:respect and communication. Respect is shown, for example, by asking theirschedule when you propose work, and by always saying, "Thank you." Inaddition, if they have expertise in a job, only give advice on how to do it ifthey ask.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Most attempts at communication are not completely successful. (In theclassroom this problem is reflected in my maxim: "I can teach faster thanthey can learn.") Thus, the golden rule of communication is "Say untoothers what you believe others have said unto you." After giving yourinstructions, always ask your RA to explain what she thought you asked her todo. (Do this in a way that makes it clear you consider yourself at fault forany miscommunication. Perhaps: "I didn't explain that very well. Can youtell me what you are planning to do?") If they don't repeat back to metheir understanding of my instructions, then it is unlikely the job will beaccomplished as I expect.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: : In economics research begun in year tusually leads to a first draft in year t+1 or t+2. Circulating it andpresenting it at a seminar or two brings us to year t+3. Submit it to a journaland they will (if you are lucky) ask for a revision in year t+4, which youmight complete that year. If so, they could accept it as fast as year t+5, butit might not come out till year t+6. On the one hand, many papers can move fromconception to publication in less than six years; on the other hand, manypapers take more.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Count back from the time you need to submit your tenure file. If you arethree years away and your case is less than 100% solid, don't begin any newresearch! At this point your priority must be to move working papers and paperswith requested revisions into the Accepted pile.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: This is just one in a series of David Levine's Cheap Advice. Collect themall! Dazzle your friends!

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p a span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p a span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p a span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p a span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Write to David Levine, Haas School of Business, University of California,Berkeley CA 94720; levine@haas.berkeley.edu for additional Cheap Advice, or togive Cheap Advice back to the source. Feedback is always appreciated.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div h1 a span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div h1 span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div h2 span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Authors must work hard to make their results easy to follow. Thus, tablesmust be comprehensible by themselves. That is, a reader should be able tounderstand a table without reference to the text (and preferably withoutreference to other tables). The converse rule is that the text should stand byitself, even if a reader ignores the tables.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: should be self-explanatory. The text should flowwithout ever showing that the reader has encountered a variable name. Forexample, "Each plant visit by a social scientist corresponded to 3.1%higher voluntary turnover per month (SE = .9%, P < .05)" is much betterthan "The coefficient of SCISTUD on VOLTUR was .031 (.009)," which isbetter than "S and V were significantly related." In short, nobodyshould know what passed between you and your computer in the middle of thenight. Name your dummy variable

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p i span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p i span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p i span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Often variables are proxies for conceptual variables. If you want to measurecomplexity, but your variable is log(employment), name the variable

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p i span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: (if all variables are expressed in logs) or

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p i span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p i span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: has number and a meaningful title: "Wages Do Not Risewith Tenure," not "Wages."

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: All statistical tests include the name of the test, the test statistic, andthe significance level. Include a brief description of complex procedures atthe bottom of the table. Remind readers of the meaning of complicatedvariables.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: lists the dependent variable and sample size.If one of these is constant for an entire table, list it only once. Alwaysinclude measures of goodness of fit such as R� or log-likelihood. Usuallyinclude a test of the significance of the entire regression (such as an F testfor ordinary least squares), and appropriate residual diagnostics (such asDurbin-Watson statistics and heteroskedasticity tests).

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: should include standard errors or t statistics, and someindication of statistical significance (P values or * for P

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span span
content: For very large datasets it makes sense todemand a higher degree of certainty, so only report P < .01.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Include a meaningful number of digits, usually at two or three significantplaces. Neither .34849560 (3.132534) nor 0.00 (SE = 0.00, P < .001) isuseful. Sometimes multiply or divide a variable by 10 so the coefficient is ina meaningful range.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Always in the text, and often in the tables, translate the coefficients ofinterest into words. For example, convert logit coefficients to measure how aone-unit change in the variable affects the probability of the occurrence ofthe event (dP/dX). Translate hazard rate coefficients to show how a one unitchange in the variable affects the expected time until some event occurs:"If the union local is in a city, its expected lifetime was four monthsshorter than if it was rural."

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Also, always explain whether the effect is large or not, perhaps bycomparing its size to something readers understand. For example, the importanceof marital status on wages can be expressed as how many years of education arerequired to raise wages by as much. Sometimes standardized coefficients(expressed in standard deviation units) are useful: "A one month increasein training (approximately one standard deviation) corresponds to 4 percentlower turnover (approximately one half of a standard deviation)."

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Effect sizes from Lisrel, factor analysis, path analysis, ordered logits,etc., are hard to understand. Thus, explain the size as well as the statisticalsignificance of the important effects.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: : Most authors focus on whether coefficientsare statistically significantly different from zero at the 5 percentlevel.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p sub span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: isstatistically significant from zero at the 5% level, but b

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p sub span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: is not,some authors write as if b

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p sub span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: is different from and more importantthan b

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p sub span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: At a minimum, authorsshould focus on confidence intervals, and explicitly test if b

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p sub span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p sub span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: should be included for the referee, although they donot always need to be in the paper. Usually include means, standard deviations,units, sources, geographical region covered, and sample size. Usually includesummary statistics for control variables as well as for the main variables ofinterest. Include the statistics for the un-logged version of any importantvariables you use in log form. If your paper computes important and meaningfulintermediate results (residuals from a first-stage equation, for example),include their summary statistics.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Often give the referee a table of correlations of either the main variablesor of all the variables.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Use simple statistical procedures to complement fancier analyses. Manypapers have a simple comparison of means as their main result (to be formalizedand measured more precisely in later sections). If your paper has such acomparison at its core, then present the unadjusted means (e.g., men vs. women,or

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p st1:country-region span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p st1:country-region st1:place span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: , like tables, are supposed to be comprehensiblewithout reference to the text, and the text without reference to the figure.Place labels (in words, not symbols or variable names) and units on axes.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: worthy of being in your paper can be expressed as asentence. Do so. Many economic theories generate an interesting first-ordercondition. Restate it in words: "At the optimum, a dollar spent today mustbring the same utility as a dollar spent tomorrow, suitably discounted."

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: present the question the paper will answer. Since socialscientists are not mystery writers, abstracts also summarize the results.Inability to write an abstract of fewer than 100 words often indicates deeperproblems with the paper.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div h2 span
content: Robustness checks and limitations of the study

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: No research is perfect. This section presents a checklist of commonimperfections in empirical research. Discuss the limitations of your paper andplausible alternate explanations for the results.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: face problems with the match between the actual sample andthe perfect sample. Always mention the response rates and possible responsebiases. Are responses likely to be sensitive to changes in the wording of thequestions? Do respondents have incentives to hide their attitudes? Areattitudes likely to match behaviors?

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: A naming issue appears when data undergo factor analysis or are summed intoan index. Do not merely name the factors or indices, but present a sample ofthe questions along with the factor weights. Differentiate exploratory fromconfirmatory factor analysis.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: are subject to all thedifficulties of surveys. They also fall prey to the "textbookchapters:" simultaneity, sample selection, measurement error, outliers,and so forth.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Almost all analyses shoulduse methods that adjust for clustering of the sample (as in most commondatasets) and that are robust to the presence of heteroskedasticity.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Re-analyze the data several times to checkthe specification, and make sure that your results are not sensitive to changesin the estimating technique, functional forms, control variables, and so forth.If all is well, allude to these results briefly, but do not include them in thepaper. Often include copies of these tables for the referee.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: almost always have questionable external validity. Isthere any reason to believe people in actual organizations involved in complexsocial networks making decisions that affect their careers over many years actthe way the college sophomores do in your one-hour treatment?

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Is the name you have given your treatment appropriate? If you tell one groupof people they are not worth the wage they receive, this treatment may affectself-esteem as well as perceived equity. Thus, naming the treated group

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p i span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: have limited generalizability. Explain in what sensethis case study generalizes, and outline the limits of its generalizability.What are the likely biases due to subjective perception and reporting?

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: is almost never clear in the social sciences. Commonproblems include reverse causality, selection effects, and omitted variablebias. Discuss alternative causal explanations for the results.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: These alternative channels often suggestadditional tests you might perform.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: When using instrumental variables or multi-equation methods such astwo-stage least squares and maximum likelihood, always list your instruments orother identifying assumptions. Include these lists in both the text and thetables. Justify why it is plausible that your instruments are exogenous. Bothidentification by functional form (as in many sample selection models) andinstrumenting with lagged variables require strong justification.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p u span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: : Explain the robustness of the results in"assumption space." Differentiate assumptions that are crucial fromthose that merely simplify. Even if you do not prove, explain what happens ifpreferences are not Cobb-Douglas, or if agents are not identical. Usuallyinclude detailed derivations in an appendix for the referee.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div h2 span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Go for clear exposition of substance as opposed to trying to impress readerswith big words, hard statistics, or fancy theory. Present the main conclusionsso that they will be accessible to the nonspecialist reader in the finalsection.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: Use footnotes sparingly, and Latin almost never. Don't rely on variablenames if you can spell them out. Remind readers often of the meaning of yoursymbols: often replace �

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span span span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: � with "the elasticity of substitution."Readers have to expand out the entire phrase--help them out.

tag: html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div h2 span
html body text o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype o:smarttagtype div p span
content: No article has ever suffered from too much helpful advice from colleagues.Be sure many readers look at your article. Use family, friends, colleagues fromother departments: most of your paper should be understandable even to the nonspecialist.
